title: Will ten or more of the remaining games in the 2019-2020 NBA season be canceled?
preds: There aren't ten games left to cancel
Pretty much impossible at this point.
The only thing at this point that could cancel 10 games would be an event such as a police shooting and the players then agreeing to end the season.  As pointed out by SE_Meyer.
It would take a miracle at this  point
Keeping that 1% in case of social tragedy.  Interestingly, Admin will not confirm how many games a cancelled series would count as.
Downgrade to 1% with the news of full return
Players vote to resume and play postponed games as well. Adjusted to 2% for some tail risk.

Looks like there has been a resolution to continue the playoffs.
https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/29752941/nba-players-decide-resume-playoffs
Lakers and Clippers reportedly want to cancel the season.

Clippers and Lakers considering boycotting remainder of the season. IF this is only these teams and the remaining sides play out the competition, would should be less than ten - as Mavs and Portland progress 2-3 and 1-3 down respectively (5 cancelled games total only). it would only take 2 more sides to follow to tick over the 10 match number.

https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/nba-boycott-live-updates-lakers-clippers-vote-to-end-season-after-bucks-protest-jacob-blake-shooting/live/ It's said they're intending to hurt corporate money, but I assume they will not go as far as hurting their own team, league, or paychecks. Team managers agree, so they might have a unified approach to protest in the end.
So far, I don't see games cancelled, unless Clippers and Lakers walk away for real.

Not sure if a “postponement” counts as a cancellation, but adjusting upwards until the current situation clarifies.
https://www.nba.com/article/2020/08/26/nba-games-postponed-bucks-magic-thunder-rockets-lakers-blazers
Adjusting upwards due to Bucks boycott and conversations of longer boycotts due to recent police brutality.
The NBA will finish their season.
No cases yet and the bubble is pretty secure.
Since I last updated there have been 2 weeks of no new cases.
They have gone a full month without a case. The Bubble appears to be working.
No games will be canceled unless the season is cancelled. I put the odds of the season finishing at 94%

Most likely not, but leaving room for margin of error in case guests brought covid unintentionally into the bubble. https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/2020/08/12/nba-players-coronavirus-visits-bubble-playoffs/3355587001/

I feel the need to adjust this to lower. NBA has restarted, they are maintaining zero cases, and they are approaching the playoffs. Will their attention to safety relax and allow the virus to accidentally be introduced? Or have they now entered a normality, where everyone has spent enough time in the Bubble, therefore no accidental, asymptomatic infections spread the virus, and everyone getting ready for playoffs is avoiding stupid mistakes that would expose them to the virus and thus ruin their teams' chances in this important stage? I am going for the latter. I would go for 10% but even that seems high to me now. I go for 8%.

Repeated weeks of no positive tests, only have to finish on the 13th in order to not reach the 10 game threshold of the regular season.  For the NBA to get cancelled in one week with no signs of COVID outbreak or player protests is extremely small, and thus opt for 2%.
It'll take me a while to trust the bubble.
News just in that there were 0 cases since the 29th. That means since the start of the bubble there have been 2 cases the first week and 0 cases in the last 3 weeks... very impressive.
Adjust down to success of bubble and no signs of trouble. Keeping 5% to account for potential COVID outbreaks

First week in the bubble: 2 cases
Second week: 0 cases
Third week: 0 cases

Bubble has been going quite smoothly. If the question is referring to the regular season, the largest risk factors that would cause a cancelling of these games would be a COVID outbreak or a player strike. Both are quite low and I have more analysis stated in the NBA start forecasting question.
Adjusting downwards due to no incidents already almost a month in the bubble

Wait. Baseball... where there is only *one* player who is consistently within 6' of EVERY other player on the other team is already at risk. What happens when we have a dozen players up close and personal for the entire game?? MLB doesn't have the bubble, but this is disconcerting: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/27/sports/baseball/marlins-game-canceled.html
With MLB on the cusp of being done, basketball will probably follow suit. There is no way football gets past the first few games if at all.
I think there is about a 2 out of 3 chance that this will happen, unless they shut the whole season down first.
The bubble seems to be holding.

What is the protocol for a positive test? What must a team do if a major franchise point guard that sees lots of minutes tests positive? Do you quarantine the starting lineup? What about the last team they played? How long until this becomes a 3rd string G League tournament?

I think it's more likely that the NBA would delay games rather than outright cancel them if they can at all help it. There's a lot of money at stake, and in general I think both the players and the league want to make this work. So far it appears the bubble is well-funded and well-run. As others have noted, however, there is correlated risk here: if the situation gets bad enough to cancel one game, it will likely be a lot more than one game. The families entering the bubble later on seems like the biggest risk point.
So far the bubble appears to be working. For how long remains to be seen.

There's a chance, sure. But I think the only way I see this happening is if an entire team literally pulls out of the bubble because of players choosing not to play or injuries or getting the virus. And that shouldn't happen because of the financial implications.
The other scenario is if there are too many cases and the NBA takes a call, and shuts down the postseason. While possible, I am quite confident in Adam Silver and the NBA's competency in handling this.
If one is cancelled, it’s likely a lot more than 1 is cancelled
Continuing to bring this down as a breakout early on seems less and less likely.
The NBA will not cancel any more games barring some major incident.
If the number nears 10 then I think the season is in jeopardy, so it's either less than 10 for random reasons (i.e. venue issues) or it goes well above that and the season is cancelled.
I believe there is a chance they cancel some regular season games to ensure the playoffs go ahead.

Wow, 0 positives since the 13th. (And only 2 before that) This was the best time for the virus to spread, with players coming in from all over the country and world. There's still plenty of time for players/staff to get restless and break the bubble, but this is very encouraging.

There were zero positive tests in the past week since players arrived. Every report says that everything is being taken extremely seriously, players are wearing masks, there are virtually no ways off campus, any employee interacting with the players frequently (like bus drivers) are being tested daily.  There was already a lot of incentive to keep everything moving, even if there were some positive tests. This continues that trend. https://sports.yahoo.com/no-nba-players-test-positive-211836769.html

It's been 10 days since teams arrived and only 2 cases have been reported. I was impressed with the plan the NBA had and the execution seems to be strong as well. The best time for the virus to spread was the past week while players and staff were arriving from all over the country, but it does not seem to have done so.

There is too much incentive to play these games. If players get sick, they will just call up second or third string players. The idea that the virus is dangerous to these players is laughable. They are under the age of 40 and in excellent health with good lung capacity. I doubt they would even notice symptoms.  The virus is burning out. In Sweden, where they did no lockdowns, they are close to herd immunity with very few cases.

The bubble seems to be holding, but it will be harder to maintain as players continue experiencing the tedium and, shall we say, lack of companionship over an extended duration. Here’s an interesting take on the issue: https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/other-sports/could-lack-of-sex-force-players-to-break-the-nba-s-bubble-1.4305062

Updating from 35 to 34%. The only new information I got today is that players are using the anonymous hotline for protocol violations, which should slightly reduce the chance of the virus spreading widely enough for entire teams being unable to compete.

I appreciate @Tjmscott and @tmcgraw's points immensely. I think the first two weeks will tell the story and after that we can start to shave off points...
Personally I think "no" -- and there is a lot we don't know. A player could test positive, the team could test negative and be cleared to play. Perhaps players will miss games for quarantine while the team plays on. Or things fall apart terrifically and games have to be cancelled. I think in that case, if it rains, it'll pour.
With approx 75 days in the season and 71-77 games, it can be fun to shave off percentage points daily or per game as a countdown. It's probably as accurate as I can get. And a lot more fun.
I'm fine with that... look at what C19 did to tennis players.... and they stand 78' apart. Imagine what it'll be like once you have a bunch of guys sweating and breathing and spitting on each other. If a virus had hands to wring menacingly, now would be the time it would do so.
There’s just no way they will get 2 1/2 months of basketball in without this spreading and bringing cancellation of the rest of the season

Since I updated from 70 to 75 that the NBA will crown a champion by October 15th, I'm updating from 40 to 35 that 10+ games will get canceled. Only 2 players in the bubble have tested positive and they were both quarantined, so it is unlikely that the virus spread. There may be more isolated cases, but as I stated yesterday it would take multiple teams dropping out after qualifying for the playoffs for 10+ games to be canceled.
The players will not be able to keep in the bubble that long. Infections will happen and they will infect teammates and opposition before it's caught.
Some inconsequential games could be cancelled.

I can imagine a team being hit hard and having to cancel a game because they don’t have the positions they need to start, but given that they can just sign anyone to play in the restart, this seems unlikely.

I forecasted a 70% chance that the NBA crowns a champion by October 15. If this does not occur, I assume at least 10 games will have been cancelled. So my lower bound is 30%. If one or two teams drop out (as what happened with the MLS) then it is possible for the season to continue but 10 games to be canceled.  However, even if a team or two dropped out fewer than 10 games would get cancelled unless the teams had qualified for the conference semifinals. This seems likely as the MLS teams that dropped out did so before even playing a game. As of now there are 0 cases in the NBA bubble, and while it's still early the league seems to be in much better shape than the MLS.

For 10 games to be cancelled, a team needs to suffer a complete covid infection (more than just a few of its players). For this to happen, an infection needs to spread from an external source (i.e. a staff of the hotel, court of team) who comes in and out of the bubble. This is possible (75% for one or a few infections in my view) but not very likely to spread to an entire team (40% in my view as players are tested regularly). Result is 30% and I increased it by 5% reading the news about Orlando Magic player being diagnosed with covid lately, not in the bubble but shows that the infection is not far away from happening. For ten games to be cancelled, this would take one team to completely go out of the tournament, which I think will be less likely than not to be the case.

After watching some players initial reaction to the Bubble ... selfish and pouty, it is the mask argument all over again. Most are professionals.  Some will do the selfish thing. The ones who do the selfish thing will infect others. Each time they bring in new players, they have to quarantine, meaning a possibility of forfeited or canceled games.
Successful in other contact sports (European football), granted didn't restart with cases so high ... just think the NBA will be quite robust on games being played.
There is no way sports happen this year because soon after they begin, dozens of players are going to get sick. No sports get past the first few weeks.
limited "regular season" games remaining, occurring at beginning of re-start, allow for higher odds of success in terms of gains being played

The risk to these athletes is basically nil. If any get the virus they will almost certainly be asymptomatic and not have enough antibodies to test positive. according to the CDC most likely scenario, the fatality rate for people under the age of 50 who get the virus is 3 in 1 million, and those are people with pre-existing conditions, not professional athletes. There is too much money at stake. If too many players test positive, they can just bring in lower tier players. It's what they did in WWII.

So they clarified that it means “never play again”. So basically, that the season will be cancelled at some point, and this question makes you guess if there are +9 games planned on the time of cancelation?
Not that much difference from the “champion before 15/10?”- question. This is more a distinction when the cancellation will be?Don’t ompletely understand the “purpose” of this question?

Postponed = canceled , right? Let’s say they play on tuesday, some positives, precaution measures, and they reschedule.
Is that a canceled game?

There are expected to be 8 regular season games for each team (24 teams) and then four rounds of the playoff (16 teams start). It seems unlikely that the cancel more than 10 games and have an NBA champion. Canceling ten or more games would basically imply either i) they forgo the regular season aspect of the restart or ii) they do not complete the championship.  It seems to me highly improbable this experiment will work and they'll end up canceling more than 10 games. This is due to the following factors i) Players are probably not going to respect the bubble and will go out when they can.
ii) Florida is a hot spot for cases right now and it seems unlikely to abate soon. Florida is at around 7,000 new cases a day and it took New York state about 1 month to get it under control when they were at that level. 
iii) Basketball is a contact sport, if one player gets it lots of players will get it.  For those reason I'm gonna be a little more pessimistic than the crowd. I think the most likely outcome is that they cancel the regular season and just do the playoffs as they stand.
For now, I'll go with "slightly more likely than a coin toss"...
This misguided experiment will completely fail. Most remaining games will be cancelled.

While I think players contracting the virus is a legitimate risk (see other question on player numbers), I think the chance that many games are cancelled is low:
1. Cancelling a game will mess up all playoff seeding and introduce fairness issues beyond the issues that already exist
2. It signals the bubble isn’t under control From the NBA protocols of testing daily, they are going to do everything they can to keep transmission near zero, which means cancelling very few, if any, games.

I have to think on this a bit. If they are committing, they'll get their money's worth. Or things will get out of hand. What happens when a player tests positive? Do they quarantine the team? The logistics of making this work seems impossible. With about 88 regular season games, I could see this going either way. More info: https://sports.yahoo.com/2020-nba-season-restart-teams-010534942.html
The virus will make all sports more difficult.
Project most teams will finish based on rules and guidelines. There will be some spread, but not enough to cancel 10 or more games.
